summary: This document is a series of internal FBI emails from April 2023 discussing an urgent deconfliction request from FinCEN regarding the release of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails reveal the FBI's objection to releasing information due to Ghislaine Maxwell's pending appeal, and include a list of 45 names and entities submitted for review.

persons.name: Carmen
persons.context: Addressed in an email from 'Seamus' to relay the FBI's objection to FinCEN regarding the release of information related to Ghislaine Maxwell's appeal.

persons.name: Seamus
persons.context: Sent an email stating the FBI objects to the release of information due to the ongoing appeal of Ghislaine Maxwell's conviction.

persons.name: Amanda
persons.context: Addressed in an email to confirm if there was any objection to releasing information, including that mentioning Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Central subject of the FBI's objection to releasing SARs due to her pending appeal. Her conviction appeal is cited as the reason for withholding information.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the subject of the underlying civil lawsuits against banks (JP Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank) for providing financial services to him.

persons.name: Robert Trivers
persons.context: One of 10 additional names provided by FinCEN for the FBI to review and deconflict in relation to the Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Maxwell's conviction is directly related to Epstein's activities, and the FBI's objection to releasing information is tied to her appeal in the Epstein case.
Trivers is listed among names submitted by FinCEN for deconfliction in the Epstein investigation, suggesting a documented connection.

events.title: FBI Objects to SARs Release
events.description: The FBI formally objects to FinCEN releasing Suspicious Activity Reports related to Epstein, citing Ghislaine Maxwell's pending appeal.

events.title: FinCEN Deconfliction Request
events.description: FinCEN sends an urgent request to the FBI to review 45 names from investigation NY-3027571 and object if necessary to prevent SARs release in civil lawsuits.

events.title: Deconfliction Response Deadline
events.description: FinCEN sets a deadline for the FBI to respond to the deconfliction request regarding 10 additional names.

locations: Federal District Court for the SDNY
keyFacts: The FBI objected to the release of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein due to Ghislaine Maxwell's pending appeal.
FinCEN requested deconfliction on 45 names from FBI investigation NY-3027571 for potential release in civil lawsuits against JP Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank.
A judge indicated he may order the disclosure of the SARs if FinCEN did not authorize it, creating urgency for the deconfliction process.
The civil lawsuits involve an unnamed Epstein victim (and a class) suing the banks, and the U.S. Virgin Islands separately suing JP Morgan.
Some SARs referenced transactions from over a decade ago but were filed much later, after Epstein's arrest.
